COURSES.name: Survey of American Literature
COURSES.description: Introduces some of the major writers, issues and forms found in the history of American literature. The instructor determines the breadth and focus of this survey. (C or H) (WR)
COURSES.prerequisites: Prereq: ENC 1101 or test score equivalent.

COURSES.name: Issues in American Literature and Culture
COURSES.description: Introduces some of the most important issues that arise in the study of American literature and culture. The instructor determines the breadth and focus of the topic. (C or H) (WR)
COURSES.prerequisites: Prereq: ENC 1101 or test score equivalent.

COURSES.name: Surveys in American Women's Literatures
COURSES.description: Surveys traditions in American women's writings, covering a wide range of texts or focusing on a single theme, genre, period, literary movement or cultural tradition. Topics may include women's writings about feminism, family, work, nationalism or social justice; women's autobiography, poetry, experimental prose or domestic fiction; 19-century literature by women, contemporary women's poetry or colonial women's writing; realist, postmodern or sentimental fiction by American women; African American, New England, Native American, Southern or working-class writing; Chicano, Latina or lesbian literary traditions. Refer to department website.

COURSES.name: African-American Literature 1
COURSES.description: Surveys the development of African-American literature from its beginning to 1945.

COURSES.name: Asian-American Studies
COURSES.description: Variable topics or survey focus on the major issues, movements or themes in the study of Asian-American literature and culture from the beginnings to the present. Topics may include Kung Fu films, cultural nationalism and feminism, model minorities, Angel Island literature, Asian-Americans in film and media, and several major authors. Consult department website.

COURSES.name: Major Figures of American Literature and Culture
COURSES.description: In-depth focus on one major author, such as Dickinson, Twain, Faulkner, Hurston, or Morrison. Refer to department website.

COURSES.name: Race and Ethnicity
COURSES.description: Variable topics examine issues, movements, forms or themes related to race and ethnicity in American literature. Topics may include Pacific Rim cultures in America, Chicano-Latino literature, the Black Arts Movement, constructing Native America, border-crossing and migration, post-war Jewish fiction, literature and the psychology of prejudice, comparative representations of racial and ethnic experience, representing whiteness, literatures of assimilation and multi-racial identities.

COURSES.name: Beginning Fiction Writing
COURSES.description: Beginning writing fiction workshop. Starts with the basics and students read a lot of fiction (you can't be a fiction writer without reading shelves of fiction). Students write stories and their fiction is discussed in workshop. (C) (WR)
COURSES.prerequisites: Prereq: freshmen and sophomores only with ENC 1101 or test score equivalency.

COURSES.name: Beginning Poetry Writing
COURSES.description: Workshop concentrates on the basics of reading and writing poetry (in order to write you have to read, and in order to be a reader you have to be a critic). Students write poems and some are discussed in workshop. (C) (WR)
COURSES.prerequisites: Prereq: freshmen and sophomores only with ENC 1101 or test score equivalency.

COURSES.name: Fiction Writing
COURSES.description: Continues instruction in basic techniques of voice, plot and character, while introducing advanced ones. Students read a lot of good stories and write a few themselves. Samuel Johnson said, "No man but a blockhead ever wrote, except for money." Juniors or seniors who have not taken CRW 1101 or CRW 1301 must have strong composition skills. (C) (WR)
COURSES.prerequisites: Prereq: CRW 1101 or junior/senior standing.

COURSES.name: Poetry Writing
COURSES.description: Writing poetry may become an addiction. This workshop continues with matter-of-fact techniques and some fancy ones as well. Students write poems and read some difficult and thrilling poetry of the past and present. By the end, students may be able to say, with Humpty Dumpty, I can explain all the poems that ever were invented - and a good many that haven't been invented just yet. Juniors or seniors who have not taken CRW 1101 or CRW 1301 must have strong composition skills. (C) (WR)
COURSES.prerequisites: Prereq: CRW 1301 or junior/senior standing.

COURSES.name: Advanced Seminar in Fiction Writing
COURSES.description: Small workshop for students who have made their way out of beginner's workshops with sanity intact. Now the work gets more difficult, more deranged and more delightful. Emerson said, "People do not deserve to have good writing, they are so pleased with bad." Admission by manuscript review during advanced registration (refer to department website); by prerequisite during drop/add.
COURSES.prerequisites: Prereq: CRW 2100.

COURSES.name: Advanced Seminar in Poetry Writing
COURSES.description: "More reeling and writhing," as Lewis Carroll said. An intense workshop for a small group of poets who have stared at the Pacific with a wild surmise. Like Balboa - or was it Cortez? Admission by manuscript review during advanced registration (refer to department website); by prerequisite during drop/add.
COURSES.prerequisites: Prereq: CRW 1301 or CRW 2300.

COURSES.name: Senior Advanced Workshop in Fiction Writing
COURSES.description: For students who want to trouble the literary editors and readers of the future. Many members of this class have gone on to graduate school in writing. Ants eat everything that is written, said an explorer. This is a workshop for ants. Admission by manuscript review during advanced registration (refer to department website); by prerequisite during drop/add.
COURSES.prerequisites: Prereq: CRW 3110.

COURSES.name: Senior Advanced Workshop in Poetry Writing
COURSES.description: George I said, "I hate all Boets and Bainters." For battle-scarred veterans of previous workshops who now want the full treatment, this is a small workshop for serious poets who want to write their names in water, as long as they are also in the Norton Anthology. Students often go from this class into MFA programs in poetry. Admission by manuscript review during advanced registration (refer to department website); by prerequisite during drop/add.
COURSES.prerequisites: Prereq: CRW 3310.

COURSES.name: Topics for Composition
COURSES.description: Instruction in expository-argumentative writing related to one special topic selected by the instructor. Readings include variable genres from different disciplines. (C or H) (WR)
COURSES.prerequisites: Prereq: ENC 1101 or test score equivalency.

COURSES.name: Advanced Exposition
COURSES.description: Advanced composition course in methods of exposition: definition, classification, comparison and contrast, analysis, illustration and identification. (WR)
COURSES.prerequisites: Prereq: junior/senior standing and two 1000/2000-level English courses.

COURSES.name: Writing through Media
COURSES.description: The media studies equivalent of ENC 1102, Writing about Literature. Explores the practices of literacy in the context of popular culture, including cinema, television, advertising, popular fiction and journalism. (C or H) (WR)
COURSES.prerequisites: Prereq: ENC 1101 or test score equivalent.

COURSES.name: Film Analysis
COURSES.description: Introduces thinking and writing about the cinema by means of film theory and history. (C or H) (WR)
COURSES.prerequisites: Prereq: ENC 1101 or test score equivalent.

COURSES.name: The Theorists
COURSES.description: Studies one or more theorists, contemporary or historical.

COURSES.name: History of Film, Part 1
COURSES.description: History of film from its beginnings to the introduction of sound.
COURSES.prerequisites: RA

COURSES.name: Psychological Approaches to Literature
COURSES.description: Use of various psychological concepts to the application of literary study. Refer to department website.

COURSES.name: Film Studies
COURSES.description: Variable topics provide in-depth study of film genres, notable film directors, and other significant topics on subjects related to film.

COURSES.name: National Cinemas
COURSES.description: Variable topics study of the films of historically important national cinemas, such as American, French, German, Italian, Russian, Japanese.

COURSES.name: Film and Video Production
COURSES.description: Seminar on the independent and experimental uses of small-format film and video production.

COURSES.name: Independent Study
COURSES.description: For advanced students who desire to supplement the regular courses by independent reading or research under guidance.
COURSES.prerequisites: Prereq: instructor and/or department permission.

COURSES.name: Undergraduate Research in English
COURSES.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research in English. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application in English.

COURSES.name: Honors Seminar
COURSES.description: Open to English majors who have maintained an overall junior/senior level GPA of 3.5. Small seminar classes study topics in English and American literature or film.
COURSES.prerequisites: Prereq: undergraduate coordinator and/or department permission.

COURSES.name: English Internship
COURSES.description: Admission requires a written proposal of appropriate work experience from the student and a written acceptance for employment from the employer, including designation of a supervisor. Successful completion requires a written summation of the work experience from the student and a written evaluation of performance by the supervisor. (S-U)
COURSES.prerequisites: Prereq: 12 credits of 3000/4000-level work in English and undergraduate coordinator permission.

COURSES.name: Department Seminar
COURSES.description: Seminar offered on a space-available basis allowing department majors to develop their individual programs of study while focusing on a common topic.
COURSES.prerequisites: Prereq: English majors only and 9 credits of 3000/4000-level work in English.

COURSES.name: Honors Thesis Project
COURSES.description: Student selects an English faculty member to act as director for an independent research project that culminates in preparation of an honors thesis. An abstract and one copy of the thesis must be delivered to 101 Academic Advising Center by the semester deadline specified by the Honors Office.
COURSES.prerequisites: Prereq: completion of one semester of ENG 4936; undergraduate coordinator permission. Open to English honors students.

COURSES.name: Survey of English Literature: Medieval to 1750
COURSES.description: Introduces some of the major writers, issues and forms found in the history of the period. The instructor determines the breadth and focus of this survey. (C or H) (WR)
COURSES.prerequisites: Prereq: ENC 1101 or test score equivalent.

COURSES.name: Survey of English Literature: 1750 to the Present
COURSES.description: Introduces some of the major writers, issues and forms found in the history of the period. The instructor determines the breadth and focus of this survey. (C or H) (WR)
COURSES.prerequisites: Prereq: ENC 1101 or test score equivalent.

COURSES.name: The English Novel: 19th Century
COURSES.description: Includes works by such writers as Scott, Austen, Dickens, Thackeray, Eliot and Hardy.

COURSES.name: The Age of Dryden and Pope
COURSES.description: Selections from the best works of such writers as Dryden, Congreve, Addison, Swift and Pope.

COURSES.name: Victorian Literature
COURSES.description: Selections from Tennyson, Browning, C. Bronte, Wilde, G.M. Hopkins and Arnold. Examines the beliefs and paradoxes of Victorian culture through the poetry, fiction, drama, visual arts and critical theory of representative figures. Investigates the social and cultural assumptions which underlie the artists' approaches to their themes as well as the themes themselves. Refer to department website.

COURSES.name: Twentieth Century British Literature
COURSES.description: Variable topics on major works of drama, poetry or prose from twentieth-century Britain. Refer to department website.

COURSES.name: Shakespeare
COURSES.description: Studies selections from Shakespeare. Topics include tracing Shakespeare's dramatic career, concentrating on one or several genres including histories, comedies, tragedies and romances; developing the history of Shakespeare reception; approaching Shakespeare through performance, including acting and directing; and approaching Shakespeare through feminist, materialist or psychoanalytic methods. Refer to department website.

COURSES.name: Introduction to Literature
COURSES.description: Examines the important role literature has played in individuals' lives and in society, presenting a range of literary styles and genres, from different countries and historical periods. Special attention paid to development of critical skills of analysis and interpretation. (H)
COURSES.prerequisites: Prereq: ENC 1101

COURSES.name: Survey of World Literature: Ancient to Renaissance
COURSES.description: Introduces some of the major writers, issues and forms found in the history of the period. The instructor determines the breadth and focus of this survey. (C or H, and N) (WR)
COURSES.prerequisites: Prereq: ENC 1101 or test score equivalent.

COURSES.name: Survey of World Literature: 17th Century to Modern
COURSES.description: Introduces some of the major writers, issues and forms found in history of the period. The instructor determines the breadth and focus of this survey. (C or H, and N) (WR)
COURSES.prerequisites: Prereq: ENC 1101 or test score equivalent.

COURSES.name: Studies in Drama
COURSES.description: Variable topics provide in-depth study of genre such as comedy or tragedy, or of developments in periods such as the Elizabethan, Jacobean or Restoration. Refer to department website.

COURSES.name: Studies in Modern Drama
COURSES.description: Representative selections from continental, British and American playwrights. Refer to department website.

COURSES.name: The Bible as Literature
COURSES.description: Literary analysis from the Hebrew and Christian Bibles, with emphasis upon poetry and narrative. (H and N)
